ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided me with new frameworks for thinking through the topic of Socialist Realism. I was able to expand my thinking on Socialist Realism (beyond a narrow scope of texts by primarily ethnic Russian authors) and to better understand its connection to other genres.

This class was the most unusual class that I have taken in a long time but in the best sense possible. 
It allowed me to study so many things all at once: art, philosophy, politics, environment.

Discussion skills normally not developed in the School of Music and other conservatories. I especially enjoyed the open and inclusive discussion environment with the well structured classes. The final conference style activity was also beneficial in introducing me to this format of work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was clearly structured, and the professor provided us with plenty of feedback throughout the semester, which was helpful. Conversations generally flowed well and were productive. The readings were compelling and informative, and the visit to the Beinecke at the beginning of the semester was super cool. Overall, this was a great class! I don't have any suggestions for improvements.

Strengths: the syllabus. Loved it. The class discussions were wonderful too. For some reason, there were many students that did not always speak up, but I enjoyed the class discussions nevertheless. 
Weaknesses: Sometimes, it was hard to manage all the readings. They were all wonderful, but coming to class, it was clear that every person did different readings. Maybe picking ONE primary source and situating the secondary readings around it. So that no matter what kinds of readings each person did, we could still all contribute to one discussion.

Strengths: well-structured classes and course progression. A bit of reading from each era and more than one country. Feedback from Prof Roosien was very helpful and direct. 

Weaknesses- the format of the seminar is inherently dependent on discussion from students. When students are quiet (me) or at times underprepared, the instructor may find it difficult to carry through the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I think the course is helpful for anyone interested in thinking through Socialist Realism/the Soviet period through new lenses.

Yes, I would. 
This is one of the few Soviet Union-related classes, that successfully discusses the state ideology.
I would. Helpful content to learn and skill development opportunities.
